Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Directing Charge Transport in Hierarchical Molecular Assemblies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division, Professor James Batteas of the Texas A & M University and Professor Charles Drain of Hunter College of the City University of New York study the molecular assembly and electron transport properties of molecules that might help in electronic device miniaturization. Moore's Law, which has held for the last four decades, states that the density of transistors on an electronic device "chip" will double approximately every two years, making electronic devices smaller, faster and more powerful. A pressing question is whether Moore's Law will continue into the future or has it reached its fundamental limits. Professors Batteas and Drain study metal-organic complexes known as porphyrinoids, found in nature as the active component of hemoglobin and chlorophyll, to aid in these developments. They design, synthesize and evaluate the conductive properties of porphyrinoids assembled into specific structures on surfaces. Using imaging techniques such as atomic force microscopy (AFM) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), the team can place individual molecules into precise arrangements on surfaces and measure not only their assembled structure at the molecular level but also how the structure controls the movement of electrons through the molecules. This research has broader impacts in science and technology, and enables the rational design of potential molecular electronic devices, including enhanced photovoltaics, chemical sensors and molecular electronics. The team also trains students, for broader impacts in education, in fundamental materials chemistry, preparing them for the 21st century high technology jobs sector.

Professor Batteas and Professor Drain study how to design, synthesize and evaluate the conductive properties of porphyrinoids assembled on metal surfaces with an eye toward the implementation of hybrid molecular-based devices for photonics applications, including enhanced photovoltaics, chemical sensors and molecular based electronics. The electroactive properties and self-assembly of robust porphyrinoids can be readily tuned through chemical synthesis using simple high yield reactions that facilitate commercial viability, making them attractive targets to be integrated as active components in electronic devices. In this project porphryinoids are assembled on Au surfaces in precise architectures via a combination of nanolithography and directed click-chemical reactions to create nanoscopic assemblies of less than 10 nm in lateral dimension. Characterization methods (time resolved florescence, UV-visible absorption, STM and AFM) are applied to understand how local molecular interactions influence electron transport properties in small molecule assemblies, how spatial confinement of molecules on a surface influence their resulting assembly process and the structures that can be formed, and how the assembled architectures control electron transport. Broader impacts of the research result in an improved fundamental understanding of the assembly and electron transport properties of the porphryiods, with potential to influence molecular electronic device and solar light harvesting applications. Broader impacts through education and outreach incorporate aspects of the work, including atomic scale imaging, nanolithography, molecular self-assembly and nanoscale electronics, into demonstrations for elementary school students as part of a weeklong summer camp on Nanotechnology (at Texas A&M University), and into the undergraduate and graduate classrooms at Texas A&M University and CUNY Hunter College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 4 years, this collaborative NSF project at Texas A&M University and Hunter College of the City University of New York on Collaborative Research: Directing Charge Transport in Hierarchical Molecular Assemblies, has focused on understanding fundamental issues related to electron transport in electroactive molecules appended to surfaces that can be used as the functional components of enabling technologies aimed at mitigating energy consumption in electronic devices, or as elements for harnessing solar energy. In particular we have investigated two main classes of materials. These include porphyrins, whose rich photochemistry and ubiquitous presence in nature as part of light harvesting in photosynthesis, make them exceptional light harvesting and charge transport materials. We have also studied diacetylene based compounds, which, when assembled on surfaces, can be photopolymerized to create well defined nanoscale architectures, the dimensions of which when tuned, provide an apt means of controlling their electronic properties. In both of these systems, we have focused on understanding the interplay of molecular architecture, electronic structure, and intermolecular interactions, with the goal of informing the design of electroactive elements that can help form the base materials to enable new technologies (e.g. neuromorphic computing elements, that require very little energy) that can have a significant impact on the future of US energy independence and sustainability. To investigate the materials, a combination of experimental methods were employed to examine how electrons flow through molecules that have been appended to surfaces in controlled geometries. The experimental studies included the design and synthesis of the porphyrins and diacetylenic molecules with specific functional linkages that would allow for their electronic structure to be systematically altered, and to then examine how these molecules assemble on surfaces. Their surface assembled structures were examined by atomic force microscopy (AFM) and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), which were also utilized to investigate their electronic properties and ability to transport charge. The use of these microscopies allowed us to examine these properties on the single molecule level, and to then build upon these structures using nanolithography to construct molecular assemblies with precise architectures to make nanoscaled islands of the porphyrins or diacetylenes on metal surfaces. From these studies we demonstrated that by forming molecular islands on the order of 5 - 10 nm in dimension, that these molecular systems exhibited quantum-dot like behavior, whereby tuning the island size afford direct control over the local density of states, permitting new electronic states to be formed that may enable low voltage molecular based computing elements to potentially be realized, especially when working with the photopolymerized diacetylene thiols on Au. We are continuing to investigate these phenomena, as this could become a game changing technology for the design of new molecular electronics elements. We are also seeking to examine how coupling these molecules with metallic nanostructures may provide design elements for new quantum optical devices and chemical sensors.

Beyond the fundamental research activities support by the grant, additional broader impacts included providing students participating in this project (ranging from junior high and high school students, up through graduate school) with cross-disciplinary education and training in areas of materials science and engineering, surface chemistry, nanoscience and nanotechnology. Such broad training diversifies student backgrounds preparing them for US initiatives in high technology, with students supported from this work going on to take positions in academia (UC Davis), national labs (Oak Ridge National Lab) as well as in the high technology sector (Intel Corporation). This project has also involved the development of outreach activities through hands on demonstrations as part of the Chemistry Open House at Texas A&M University, where we engaged elementary school children in experiments on nanoscience. We also developed a week long Nanotechnology Camp for 8th-11th graders, to help sustain the STEM pipeline, which we now offer each summer at Texas A&M University as part of our Youth Adventure Program. The PI and students involved with this project punlished the results of this research and presented the results of this work in numerous scientific venues.
